messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>On 9/10/07, hyysguyang <hyysguyang@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>> I do this in my daily life but many friend don't agree with me. there
>> opinion is that should not write so much code.
>>
>>
>
>Your friends have a point.
>
>Just like everything else, use TDD sparingly. I understand you are
>currently doing this as an exercise, so it's healthy to take it to
>extremes and do everything by the book in order to learn, but in your
>real work, use your judgment and decide for yourself when you are
>indeed writing too much code, in which case it's probably safer to go
>the usual route (get your code to work, then write tests for it).
>
>The downside of TDD is that you can end up writing a lot of tests for
>business code that you quickly throw away and rewrite, so the amount
>of churn can be quite high.
>
>
I haven't seen that. Maybe we are doing things differently.

One thing that is underemphasized in all of this, though, is TDD's
effect on design. When you write tests after the fact it's easier to end
up with classes that are rather monolithic. An example, close to this
list: I wrote a tool a while back which shows the internal dependency
structure of classes. I ran it on a version of JUnit and the pictures
are small and balanced. Most of the classes have roughly the same amount
of internal structure. Afterwards, I ran it on TestNG and I noticed that
some of the classes are rather large and they contain a lot of internal
structure.

I'm not saying this is good or bad, JUnit and TestNG have different
implementation styles. In any case, I don't think that a class like your
TestRunner in TestNG, would look the same if it was implemented
incrementally via TDD.

Michael Feathers
